visual_elements.description: Figure 25: Front elevation showing an accessory structure (garage-like building) with a sloped roof. A dashed line indicates the daylight plane, starting from a vertical line labeled 'Side lot line' and sloping downwards towards the building. Dimensions are shown for height from average grade (8') and maximum height of building (12'). A '3' is indicated above the sloped line, and a '1' is indicated at the corner where the vertical and sloped lines meet. The ground is depicted with cross-hatching.

A square diagram with 'Front' labeled on the left side, 'Side' labeled on the bottom side, and 'Rear' labeled on the right side. The square is divided into three sections by lines originating from the center. Arrows indicate directions: one arrow points upwards in the 'Front' section, one arrow points downwards in the 'Side' section, and one arrow points rightwards in the 'Rear' section. This diagram appears to illustrate the orientation of the lot.

Figure 26: Side elevation showing an accessory structure (garage-like building) with a sloped roof. A dashed line indicates the daylight plane, starting from a vertical line labeled 'Rear lot line' and sloping downwards towards the building. Dimensions are shown for height from average grade (8') and maximum height of building (12'). A '3' is indicated above the sloped line, and a '1' is indicated at the corner where the vertical and sloped lines meet. The ground is depicted with cross-hatching.

sections: Fig 25 Front elevation showing accessory-structure daylight plane at the side of the lot
Note: For accessory buildings near the rear & side lot lines, a hipped-gable roof is often the best solution for complying with the accessory-structure daylight plane.
Fig 26 Side elevation showing accessory-structure daylight plane at the rear of the lot

additional_notes: Page number '32' is located at the bottom left corner.
The main heading 'Accessory structure daylight plane (sides & rear)' is highlighted with a light grey rectangular bar behind it.
